description: Perhaps imitative. Akin to Dutch jak (“disgusting”). First appeared in the 1960s.

examples: I fetched an orange from a basket and peeled it  […]  “Make sure you peel as much of the yuck off as possible,” she said. “I hate the yuck."

verbs.description: yuck (third-person singular simple present yucks, present participle yucking, simple past and past participle yucked)

entries.meaning: The sound made by a whole-hearted laugh.
examples: Given this insecurity, the creators of “The Simpsons” took an extraordinary risk: they decided not to use a laugh track. On almost all other sitcoms, dialogue was interrupted repeatedly by crescendos of phony guffaws (or by the electronically enhanced laughter of live audiences), creating the unreal ebb and flow of sitcom conversation, in which a typical character’s initial reaction to an ostensibly humorous remark could only be to smile archly or look around while waiting for the yucks to die down.

verbs.description: yuck (third-person singular simple present yucks, present participle yucking, simple past and past participle yucked)

entries.meaning: (often followed by "up") To laugh or joke.

verbs.description: yuck (third-person singular simple present yucks, present participle yucking, simple past and past participle yucked)
